channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: The Saturday Profile: A Sadrist Governor Is a Folk Hero to Iraqis
item.description: For Iraqis frustrated with poor services, sectarian politics and violence, the governor, Ali Dwai, provides a rare example of democracy’s potential.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times

item.title: Judge Allows René González, One of ‘Cuban Five’ Spies, to Stay in Cuba
item.description: A federal judge in Miami said a convicted spy can stay in Cuba, where he went for his father’s funeral, if he renounces his American citizenship.
item.dc:creator: By DAMIEN CAVE

item.title: Obama Seeks to Banish Stereotypical Image of Mexico
item.description: In a speech to a friendly audience of students in Mexico City, President Obama said it was time to embrace a new image of the country as an emerging power.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD and MICHAEL D. SHEAR
item.media:description: President Obama spoke at the National Anthropology Museum in Mexico City on Friday.

item.title: Mortar Shells Hit Damascus Airport
item.description: Syrian rebels fired two mortar shells at Damascus International Airport outside the capital on Friday, state news media reported.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Iran Eases Prison Conditions for Ex-Marine
item.description: Relatives see possible signs that Iran eventually could release a man who has been held there for nearly two years on suspicions of spying.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:credit: Iranian State Television, via European Pressphoto Agency

item.title: The Met Plans to Return Statues to Cambodia
item.description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art said new research backed up Cambodian claims that two 10th-century statues were improperly removed from the Koh Ker temple complex.
item.dc:creator: By TOM MASHBERG and RALPH BLUMENTHAL
item.media:credit: The Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York

item.title: In China, Nixon Grandson Commemorates 1972 Visit
item.description: The trip by Christopher Nixon Cox, 100 years after President Richard M. Nixon’s birth, was organized to lionize both the president’s and the Communist Party’s accomplishments.
item.dc:creator: By DAN LEVIN
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: Christopher Nixon Cox, grandson of President Richard M. Nixon, and his wife, Andrea Catsimatidis Cox, visiting Tiananmen Square.

item.title: Europe Looks to Merkel of Germany to Revive Economy
item.description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany faces the task of getting Europe growing again while continuing to advocate her austerity policies to the German electorate.
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel, center, in Berlin last week.

item.title: Syria’s Unrest Puts Israelis on Alert
item.description: Errant munitions from Syria’s conflict have landed in the Golan Heights some 30 times. But the concern runs deeper along what was long one border Israel didn’t have to worry much about.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: The newly built Israeli border with Syria, a 16-foot steel obstacle equipped with sophisticated sensors.

item.title: The Lede: Mariela Castro, First Daughter of Cuba, Visits Icon of America's Revolution
item.description: The Liberty Bell received a visit on Friday from Cuba’s premier sexologist, who is also the daughter of President Raúl Castro.
item.dc:creator: By FRANCES ROBLES
item.media:description: Mariela Castro, the daughter of President Raúl Castro, during an appearance at an academic conference in San Francisco in 2012.

item.title: Wedding Guests’ Special Landing Buffets South African Leader
item.description: The use of a military air base to transport civilian guests to the wedding of a wealthy family has set off outrage.
item.dc:creator: By LYDIA POLGREEN
item.media:credit: The New Age, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Guests watch as Vega Gupta and Aakash Jahajgarhia are pulled across a pool on a float during their wedding ceremony at Sun City's Palace of the Lost City in South Africa.

item.title: Death Toll in Bangladesh Building Collapse Tops 500
item.description: The number of dead rose to 517 on Friday, as investigators continued interrogating the building’s owner and others arrested.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY
item.media:description: A Bangladeshi woman looked at a wall filled with portraits of missing people on Friday near the collapsed Rana Plaza building.

item.title: Irish Catholic Church Condemns Abortion Legislation
item.description: Irish bishops called the legislation, which would permit abortions in cases where a threat existed to a woman’s life, morally unacceptable.
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS DALBY

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: This Woman’s Place Is in Her Kitchen
item.description: Christine Ferber persuaded her father that she could make jam to sell in the Alsace region of France. Now she ships that jam all over the world.
item.dc:creator: By HANNAH OLIVENNES
item.media:description: Christine Ferber, whose jams are served at some of the top hotels in the world. “Jam is a very feminine process,” she says. “It demands care and patience, qualities men don't often have.”

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Freedom Still Eludes the Press, Despite the Arab Spring
item.description: As the United Nations marked World Press Freedom Day, a survey ranked the Middle East at the bottom of an international score card of media freedom. Syria, where at least 23 reporters and 58 citizen-journalists have been killed since March 15, 2011, was unsurprisingly the most perilous place for journalists.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:description: Bassem Youssef, a popular television host in Egypt, entering the state prosecutor's office in Cairo, March 31, after being accused of insulting Islam and the country's leader.

item.title: Dell Products Make Their Way, Circuitously, to Syria
item.description: A company in Dubai bought large amounts of computer equipment from Dell that ended up in Syria despite sanctions, documents show.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By RON NIXON

item.title: Opposition in Tight Race to Take Power in Malaysian Election
item.description: The results of Sunday’s vote will bring either a continuation of decades of leadership by the current government or the nation’s first handover of power.
item.dc:creator: By JOE COCHRANE

item.title: Euro Area Recession Is Expected to Deepen
item.description: The economic outlook for the European Union has deteriorated and the unemployment and recession blighting the euro area are expected to worsen, the European Commission warned on Friday.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER

item.title: Cecilia Muñoz’s Perseverance in Immigration Push
item.description: Cecilia Muñoz, a longtime activist, was denounced after she joined the Obama administration and defended its deportation policy. But her loyalty appears to have paid off.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR

item.title: British Independence Party Gains in Local Elections
item.description: The United Kingdom Independence Party, which wants Britain to leave the European Union, consolidated its position as an emerging force.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE and ALAN COWELL

item.title: The Lede: Investigation Suggests American Journalist Missing in Syria ‘Likely’ Held by Government
item.description: James Foley, an American journalist who has been missing in Syria, “was most likely abducted by a pro-regime militia group and subsequently turned over to Syrian government forces,” according to GlobalPost, the news site for which he was a freelance correspondent.
item.dc:creator: By LIAM STACK
item.media:description: James Foley, an American journalist, has been missing in Syria since November.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: May 3
item.description: Indian cinema turns 100.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A man walking past a mural of Bollywood actor Amitabh Bachchan in Mumbai, Maharashtra. The Indian film industry celebrated 100 years of its existence Friday, commemorating the release of India's first feature film, "Raja Harishchandra," on May 3, 1913.

item.title: James Dobbins to Be Named Representative for Afghanistan and Pakistan
item.description: James Dobbins, a diplomat with a history of difficult assignments, will be appointed as special representative for the troubled region, an administration official said.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER

item.title: Irish Catholic Church Condems Abortion Legislation
item.description: Irish bishops call the legislation, which would permit abortions in cases where a threat existed to a woman’s life, morally unacceptable.
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS DALBY

item.title: Wines of The Times: Embracing the Potential of the Little Spanish Grape That Could
item.description: Exploring the albariño, as much a brand name for Spanish whites as pinot grigio is for Italian.
item.dc:creator: By ERIC ASIMOV
